MC: Which of the following descriptions most accurately portrays emergency medical services (EMS)?

column3: a) A vast network of advanced life support (ALS) providers who provide definitive emergency care in the prehospital setting
b) A team of health care professionals who are responsible for providing emergency care and transportation to the sick and injured
c) A system composed exclusively of emergency medical responders (EMRs) and emergency medical technicians (EMTs) who are responsible for providing care to sick and injured patients
d) A team of paramedics and emergency physicians who are responsible for providing emergency care to critically injured patients

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Introduction			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 3			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-1 Define emergency medical services (EMS) systems.
MC
The standards for prehospital emergency care and the individuals who provide it are typically regulated by the:

column3: a) state office of EMS.
b) regional trauma center.
c) American Heart Association.
d) National Registry of EMTs.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Introduction			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 5			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-2 Name the four levels of EMT training and licensure.
MC
An EMS provider who has extensive training in various aspects of advanced life support (ALS) is called a(n):

column3: a) EMT.
b) paramedic.
c) advanced EMT (AEMT).
d) EMR.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Introduction			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 4			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-2 Name the four levels of EMT training and licensure.
MC
EMT training in nearly every state meets or exceeds the guidelines recommended by the:

column3: a) National Registry of EMTs.
b) individual state’s EMS protocols.
c) National Association of EMTs.
d) National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Introduction			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 5			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-2 Name the four levels of EMT training and licensure.
MC
According to the National EMS Scope of Practice Model, an EMT should be able to:

column3: a) assist a patient with certain prescribed medications.
b) insert a peripheral IV line and infuse fluids.
c) administer epinephrine via the subcutaneous route.
d) interpret a basic (ECG) rhythm and treat accordingly.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 9			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-5 Describe the levels of EMT training in terms of sets of knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed for each of the following: EMR, EMT, AEMT, and paramedic.
MC
Cardiac monitoring, pharmacologic interventions, and other advanced treatment skills are functions of the:

column3: a) EMT.
b) paramedic.
c) AEMT.
d) EMR.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Introduction			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 4			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-2 Name the four levels of EMT training and licensure.
MC
Which of the following criteria is required to become licensed and employed as an EMT?

column3: a) Demonstration of the ability to lift and carry at least 200 pounds
b) Proof of immunization against certain communicable diseases
c) A minimum of 60 college credit hours that focus on health care
d) Successful completion of a recognized bystander CPR course

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Licensure Requirements			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 7			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Licensure Requirements			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-3 Describe EMT licensure criteria; include how the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) applies to employment as an EMT.
MC
If an EMT candidate has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, he or she should:

column3: a) wait at least 24 months before taking another state-approved EMT class.
b) send an official request to the National Registry of EMTs (NREMT) to seek approval to take the EMT exam.
c) recognize that any such conviction will disqualify him or her from EMT licensure.
d) contact the state EMS office and provide its staff with the required documentation.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Licensure Requirements			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 7			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Licensure Requirements			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-3 Describe EMT licensure criteria; include how the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) applies to employment as an EMT.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 is correct?

column3: a) The ADA applies only to individuals with a diagnosed and well-documented physical disability.
b) The minimum number of hours required to successfully complete an EMT course is less for candidates who are disabled.
c) The ADA prohibits employers from failing to provide full and equal employment to those who are disabled.
d) According to the ADA, EMT candidates with a documented disability are exempt from taking the NREMT exam.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Licensure Requirements			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 7			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Licensure Requirements			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-3 Describe EMT licensure criteria; include how the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) applies to employment as an EMT.
MC
As an EMT, you may be authorized to administer aspirin to a patient with chest pain based on:

column3: a) the patient’s condition.
b) medical director approval.
c) an order from a paramedic.
d) the transport time to the hospital.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 14			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-8 Describe how medical direction in an EMS system works and the EMT’s role in the process.
MC
According to the National EMS Scope of Practice Model, an EMT would require special permission from the medical director and the state EMS office to:

column3: a) insert a peripheral intravenous catheter.
b) apply and interpret data from a pulse oximeter.
c) use an automatic transport ventilator.
d) give aspirin to a patient with chest pain.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 10			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-5 Describe the levels of EMT training in terms of sets of knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed for each of the following: EMR, EMT, AEMT, and paramedic.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding the NREMT is correct?

column3: a) The NREMT is a governmental agency that certifies EMTs.
b) The NREMT regulates EMS training standards.
c) The NREMT is the exclusive certifying body for EMTs.
d) The NREMT provides a national standard for EMS testing.

Which of the following scenarios involves the administration of ALS?

column3: a) A 48-year-old patient whose airway is secured with a supraglottic device
b) A 53-year-old patient who is assisted with his prescribed nitroglycerin
c) A 61-year-old patient who is receiving humidified supplemental oxygen
d) A 64-year-old patient who is given aspirin for suspected cardiac chest pain

Which of the following skills would a layperson most likely be trained to perform before the arrival of EMS?

column3: a) Obtaining a manual blood pressure
b) Bleeding control using a tourniquet
c) Insertion of an oropharyngeal airway
d) Administration of supplemental oxygen

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 10			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-5 Describe the levels of EMT training in terms of sets of knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed for each of the following: EMR, EMT, AEMT, and paramedic.
MC
Which of the following skills or interventions is included at every level of prehospital emergency training?

column3: a) Oral glucose for hypoglycemia
b) Automated external defibrillation
c) Intranasal medication administration
d) Use of a manually triggered ventilator

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 10			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-5 Describe the levels of EMT training in terms of sets of knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed for each of the following: EMR, EMT, AEMT, and paramedic.

EMRs such as firefighters, law enforcement officers, and park rangers are an integral part of the EMS system because:

column3: a) they are usually trained to assist paramedics with certain procedures.
b) they often arrive at the scene before the ambulance and EMTs.
c) the average response time for the EMT crew is approximately 15 minutes.
d) they can initiate certain ALS procedures before EMS arrival.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 10			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-6 Recognize the presence of other first responders at a scene with EMS training, some knowledge of first aid, or merely good intentions, and their need for direction.
MC
The ____________ deals with the well-being of the EMT, career progression, and EMT compensation.

column3: a) human resources department
b) office of the medical director
c) EMS administrator or chief
d) local public health department

The person who is responsible for authorizing EMTs to perform emergency medical care in the field is the:

column3: a) shift supervisor.
b) medical director.
c) EMS administrator.
d) field training officer.

MC
Which of the following statements regarding the EMS medical director and an EMT’s scope of practice is correct?

column3: a) The EMS medical director can expand the EMT’s scope of practice but cannot limit it without state approval.
b) The EMS medical director can expand or limit an individual EMT’s scope of practice without state approval.
c) An EMT’s scope of practice is exclusively regulated by the state EMS office, not the EMS medical director.
d) An EMT’s scope of practice may be expanded by the medical director after proper training and state approval.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Levels of Training			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 10			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Levels of Training			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-6 Recognize the presence of other first responders at a scene with EMS training, some knowledge of first aid, or merely good intentions, and their need for direction.
MC
Which type of medical direction do standing orders and protocols describe?

column3: a) Radio
b) Online
c) Off-line
d) Direct

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 14			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-8 Describe how medical direction in an EMS system works and the EMT’s role in the process.
MC
Which of the following is a specific example of the Mobile Integrated Healthcare (MIH) model?

column3: a) EMTs assess a patient whose lung disease is “acting up”
b) The paramedic administers a patient’s flu vaccination
c) EMTs respond to a woman who complains of high fever
d) Paramedics pick up a patient from an acute care clinic

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 15			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-9 Define mobile integrated health care and community paramedicine.
MC
The continuous quality improvement (CQI) process is designed to:

column3: a) administer punitive actions to EMTs who do not follow local protocols.
b) identify areas of improvement and provide remedial training if needed.
c) ensure that all EMTs maintain licensure through the state EMS office.
d) focus specifically on the quality of emergency care provided to the patient.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 16			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
Which of the following errors is an example of a knowledge-based failure?

column3: a) An EMT gives the correct drug to a patient, although his protocols clearly state that he is not authorized to do so.
b) Due to an improperly applied cervical collar, a patient’s spinal injury is aggravated and he is permanently disabled.
c) A patient is given nitroglycerin by an EMT who did not obtain proper authorization from medical control first.
d) An EMT administers the wrong drug to a patient because she did not know the pertinent information about the drug.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 17			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
Continuing education in EMS serves to:

column3: a) confirm research and statistical findings in prehospital care.
b) maintain, update, and expand the EMT’s knowledge and skills.
c) enforce mandatory attendance at agency-specific training.
d) provide an ongoing review and audit of the EMS system.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 19			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
Obtaining continuing medical education is the responsibility of the:

column3: a) individual EMT.
b) State Bureau of EMS.
c) EMS training officer.
d) EMS medical director.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 19			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
Which of the following is an example of a primary prevention strategy?

column3: a) Community awareness programs that emphasize the dangers of drinking and driving
b) The construction of a guardrail on a dangerous curve following a fatal motor vehicle crash
c) Protecting a patient’s spine from further injury after a fall from a significant height
d) Teaching a group of new parents how to perform one- and two-rescuer infant CPR

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 20			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-11 Characterize the EMT’s role in disease and injury prevention and public education in the community.
MC
The determination that prompt surgical care in the hospital is more important than performing time-consuming procedures in the field on a major trauma patient is based mostly on:

column3: a) EMS research.
b) local protocols.
c) the lead EMT’s decision.
d) regional trauma guidelines.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 20			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-11 Characterize the EMT’s role in disease and injury prevention and public education in the community.
MC
Why are prehospital emergency care guidelines updated on a regular basis?

column3: a) Statistical data indicate that an increasing number of people are being diagnosed with a particular illness.
b) EMS providers should be encouraged to actively participate in research and become familiar with data analysis.
c) Additional information and evidence indicate that the effectiveness of certain interventions has changed.
d) The federal government requires the implementation of changes to existing emergency care protocols at least every five years.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 21			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
If a defibrillator manufacturer claims that its device terminates ventricular fibrillation on the first shock 95% of the time, you should:

column3: a) avoid purchasing the device because this claim is unrealistic.
b) recognize that this does not mean the device will save more lives.
c) purchase the device based solely on the manufacturer’s claim.
d) determine which device the American Heart Association recommends.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Components of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 20			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Components of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-10 Explain the purpose of the EMS continuous quality improvement (CQI) process.
MC
An appropriate demonstration of professionalism when your patient is frightened, demanding, or unpleasant is to:

column3: a) continue to be nonjudgmental, compassionate, and respectful.
b) demand that the patient remain quiet and cooperative during transport.
c) ignore the patient’s feelings and focus on his or her medical complaint.
d) reassure the patient that everything will be all right, even if it will not be.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Roles and Responsibilities of the EMT			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 22			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Roles and Responsibilities of the EMT			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 1-12 Describe the roles and responsibilities of the EMT.
MC
The EMT certification exam is designed to:

column3: a) rank EMTs based on performance on the certification exam.
b) identify those EMTs who are prepared for advanced levels of training.
c) provide EMTs with the best possible wage once certification is achieved.
d) ensure that EMTs are competent and have the same level of knowledge and skills.

MC
EMS as we know it today had its origins in 1966 with the publication of:

column3: a) the Emergency Medical Services Act.
b) the Department of Transportation’s White Paper: Death and Dying.
c) Emergency Care and Transportation of the Sick and Injured.
d) Accidental Death and Disability: The Neglected Disease of Modern Society.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Overview of the EMS System			Subject: EMS Systems	, Page 8			Title: EMS Systems			Feedback: See Overview of the EMS System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 1-4 Discuss the historical background of the development of the EMS system.
